WRITING.TITLE: The Problem with Categories:
WRITING.TEXT: A brief intro: I expected the meta to shift in this direction as soon as I realized the meta was spiralling to "an always bigger buff to an always smaller group of units". I came to the game with Super Vegito and the 70% meta to all that-Type Units, whereas now we had a 120% meta to all Super or Extreme that-Type Units. I figured the next meta would be one of two choices: either a tradeoff of ki and stats the same way Int Trunks and Merged Zamasu had only +1ki; or what we got, which is an infinitely larger reduction of the character pool to choose from for an even bigger buff. Now, basically saying I told you so, here are my issues: 1. Teams from now on are going to be incredibly unbalanced. What I mean by this is categories are not Types, chosen by the Dokkan team, so if a particular team, Super-Agl lets say, is lacking something in respect to Super-Str, making the two incredibly unbalanced and pushing everybody to use one rather than the other, they can introduce a Super Agl sealer for example to balance the two (of course its an example, since the teams are both incredibly good already). With categories they'd be forced to create a card of THAT category to change the team, not just that type, which could mean having to say "Mhmm, lets add another Super Gogeta, only this one tanks"; or a new base Gotenks, or another Ss3 Gotenks, etc etc. Before this new meta, balancing the teams was easier, now we might risk them creating odd categories in order to avoid breaking the game. So not creating a category called "Saiyans" cause duh. Or excluding characters from a unit from that group to avoid breaking the game. The same way I think "Shadow Dragon Arc" is a stupid sounding category (my issue is with the Arc part) and them excluding Goku because the art is from the Baby saga is a stupid excuse to not make a team with Omega, Gogeta, Goku, and Vegeta all at a 300% buff to stats. 2. Its going to be the most annoying thing ever to actually have barely 7, maybe 8 cards to choose from in the pool. I was thinking about Ss4 Gogetas team, in JP, and basically the setup would be [[ Furry Gogeta - Int Super Gogeta - Phy Ss3 Gotenks - Phy Ssj Gotenks - Teq Ss3 Adult Gotenks - Base Form Gotenks ]]. The team itself is amazing, imagine two of the hardest hitting units in the game, Int Gogeta and Phy Ss3 Gotenks, along with the new Gogeta, having a 300% boost to their stats. Super cool and everything. My problem is that, if I lack a card, or if I want to run something different, I can't without basically shooting myself in the foot. The only other cards that fall into the fusions category are fat failure Gogeta (Veku), Ssj Adult Gotenks, and pretty much thats it. You could run Ss3 Angel Goku for that 50% and 1 ki to Teq Units, but a 200% reduction in stats in respect to the other cards would make him hit barely harder than just base Gotenks. So that makes him extremely unviable. For example, on my Vegeta team, I like to run Agl Godku quite simply because I like the card, so I prefer him over Agl SsB Vegeta. Now I don't have Ssb Vegeta, but even if I did I still wouldn't run him over Godku, even though that is the optimal unit. But if I did want to run him, having Godku still allows me to play, it's not like I'm running a Saibamen. Because the meta right now gives options that are not optimal but still viable. With the new meta coming tomorrow the optimal units to run are gonna be the only possible units to run. And that brings to the final problem: the meta ruling the game. 3. As of right now, even though both furries are out, I still have tons of friends running double Vegito Blue leads, cause in the end it makes sense to run your favorite units for a 100% buff to stats, making the game reasonably challenging in respect to the 240% boost double furries offer. With the next meta, how many people are gonna play 100% units in a 300% meta? I find it really hard to believe, but people are still gonna do it, I know I am. Just not that many. Its far more enjoyable to play with the sickest looking units even though they hit slightly less hard, but when the difference is so vast, a lot of people are gonna give that up. Tl;dr This meta will ruin the game cause [salt starts raining] 1. Categories are a shitty, restrictive, hard-to-keep-up-with idea 2. They are taking the choice away from the players in respect to the units to run 3. They are taking the choice away from the players in respect to the team to run Is it fixable? Sure, by adding some better units and by being extra careful to not create stupid categories and placing stupid units in them, by making categories slightly more broad (though not broader than the entire Super/Extreme-"that" type pool), by finding a way to slightly buff Super and Extreme Leads (I'd say 75% and +3 ki for VB and Rose and 100% and +1ki for MZ and Trunks). This keeps choice solid and the game not entirely about the current meta, still keeping the old units viable.

The team is by far the best in the game, but the moment you're (a) missing a unit (b) wanting to try some refreshing change, the team becomes unviable. It's either those characters or those characters.

Of course, thats how they can keep this meta reasonable, but its gonna be even more work for them. The fact that single units fall into more than one category is refreshing, cause you could run a unit in a hypothetically infinite number of categories, my issue is that the category itself won't offer many choices, so if lets say tomorrow a Ssj God Goku comes out with its leader skill being +150% to Saiayans category, pulling on Gogeta, other than wanting the unit itself, is going to be incredibly stupid, because the whole Fusions team would still fall into the Saiyan team.

That is exactly my point. The idea for the meta isn't bad, it's that introducing it this way, in my opinion, is fundamental for them to cash in, but isn't that appealing to me, because in truth I feel like they could have initially developed it better and then went on to release it. But again, as you put it, it gives many options for other groups of units I would have liked to see first.
Rose; buuhan; phy omega;teq golden frieza; full power frieza; janemba.

WRITING.TITLE: The Man in the Mirror
WRITING.TEXT: Is it possible I fought myself in the WT? Cause I'm pretty sure I did lol

I've read deeply into the *SPOILER ALERT AVERT YOUR EYES* Tyrion Targaryen/Blackfyre theories and the idea that's gnawing at the back of my mind is that, if it is true, he knows who he is, especially reinforced by Cersei asking him why he's siding with Daenerys. I think he found out about his real father, he knows Dany is his half sister, and he was waiting for the right moment to tell her because of the Targaryen love sibling incest thing. So he sided with her because he might have seen a chance to marry her and become King/Husband of the Queen; seeing Jon makes him realize he's always gonna be a dwarf and thus he can only aspire to be Hand. I don't think his ambition is ill-willed, he's not power hungry, he wants power to help those that need it, and he's saddened by the realization it will never happen. That's why I expect him either to die an honourable death or end up on the throne were Jon and Dany killed in the future. He would in theory have a claim tied to his blood and good intentions to reign. Juuust a theory though!
Why??

I rate that, but I'll never understand why Cooler, Super 17, Ss3 Broly, Kid Buu or Janemba deserved a spot as a 120 Lead more than Cell. I'll break it down; **Cooler** : I respect what you said, so I'll stamp my approval as Cooler as the E. Phy Lead, even though were I to choose, I would have gone with Cell. **Kid Buu** : Ooh don't get me started on Kid Buu. Ffs he wasn't even the strongest character in his arc, or the second strongest character, or the third. He wasn't even the strongest form of himself! Like literally it would have made more sense to use Buutenks, even he's more powerful than Kid Buu. He's not iconic, he's not a cool villain, he's not even that powerful. **Super 17** : Just the fact that he came from GT, and he was probably one of the worst 'serious' arcs of GT, makes me shake my head. They could have, and should have, gone with Baby, were they desperate to include GT in it. Or Syn Shenron, for the matter. They opted to use Super 17 as a 120 lead, which to me is insane. I know they wanted to put new characters, but I swear I would have rather they went with Cell. Use him as a support unit idk but he didn't deserve that spot. **Janemba** : I have a soft spot for Janemba, I really love his design and his powers, that sword and the fact that he dodges and stuff. However, I hated the idea of making opposite type, powered up reskins of him and Gogeta. Thats why I don't rate Int Gogeta or Phy Ss3 Gotenks for the matter, I'm still gonna pull on them but they didn't really try to implement anything new. And Janemba is really cool but Cell is probably the best Villain of DBZ when it comes to arc and motives, he deserved that spot more than Janemba did. **Ss3 Broly** : We all know this was vicious fanservice and nothing more, so I don't really need to say anymore. He was barely in a Videogame, he means nothing to fans, he's the worst character when it comes to motives in DB with the worst transformation in DB. Plus they really outdid themselves to make him a really bad card, so yea, great job Bamco. Cell on the other hand is probably one of the best villains ever seen in the series, with one the best set of powers, and has no usable cards. You can run Str Cell with Janemba, but not many pulled on that banner. Other than that there's Int and Teq Cell which are both pretty bad as of today, and the second form support unit to run with Broly. But it's not enough. And they could have made a really fun to use unit that maybe when he was hit by Supers that weren't deadly (e.g. on 200k hp super that hit for 160k) he would regenerate maybe half of that (or all of it to make it op) and hit that unit back with the same super, since he has that in his skillset to learn moves when he sees them. So this post has dragged on for too long, all I'm saying, **tl;dr** , I demand respect for Cell.

The only thing I hold with 99% certainty is that SB games depend so much on who scores the first goal. I win most games, but sometimes I find that when I'm distracted or careless, missing the first chance, and the AI scores the first goal, they tend to defend in godlike manners and are always quick on the turnover. When I start the game aggressive and get a one goal lead, no kidding I know I'll score 3-7 more depending on by how much I want to win. And I play on legendary. But really I think theres just different bots comanding these teams, each with its own personality, some more offensive, some more defensive. When I face the defensive AIs that are really there just for the tie, I tend to struggle much more, whereas when the other team is aggressive and tries to play I dominate. Once I get the first goal they tend to go almost all out attack leaving so much space open. This is all just a theory, don't get me wrong, but maybe the reason why the harder teams are lower rated is cause being the weaker side they try to play small team football only focused on parking the bus and countering. Every once in a while I get that 10-behind-the-ball game where the AI only defends, and those games are usually tight on the 0-0 when they get the last second counter and win.

I see a lot of people commenting about the engine, but I don't think that's the problem. Thing is, back in the old days when R2+R1+X used to be very effective for pressing, people used to be very aggressive, and with good timing skills worked out great. Now that Fifa 18 doesn't allow that kind of pressure anymore, most players act defensive and use L2 to stall with their defenders and press with their midfielders. That's why most of my skill runs happen against either Squad Battle teams on Legendary or not very experienced players. Cause smart players will probably stall with their defenders and not allow you to use skills to evade them.

Bakayoko is easy to hybrid cause he plays in a top club and is French. Gueye is unusable unless you use an all BPL team.

I did the loan, playing him as a lone CDM with stay back while attacking, and even though his workrates are M/M, I swear to f-ing God he was always attacking up front. This was bad for my team on the defensive side, but he brought a whole new game offensively. Thats why as of now I decided not to do his sbc, but if I'll ever need a Nainggolan-like midfielder I'll probably complete it. He's great offensively which is surprising, but if you need a CDM look elsewhere.

I don't agree with him, but I have the mental flexibility to understand where he's coming from. To get a 40-0 means balancing games between Fri-Sat-Sun, often getting 6-7 games under the belt by Friday morning and often finishing Sat night or Sunday morning for pros. That means that, hypothetically, pople that usually get 30-35 might wait and play the last games on Monday, when every pro will already be done with his games, thus playing Elite 3/Gold 1 players on Monday. The point of WL is challenging players by playing so many games, looking for commitment. I don't agree with the format at all, that's why I don't agree with him, but I get what he means. If I leave 10/15 games for Monday the level will be significantly lower than playing the same number of games on Sunday or Saturday. Blame EA.

As Roma has no icons despite being probably the 4th biggest club in Italy. Totti, Batistuta, Falcao, Conti, Ancelotti, Voeller, Cerezo, Aldair, Cafu all deserve icon cards over some existing in-game. Some of Man U's biggest icons are missing, like Best, Giggs, Scholes, Cantona, Yorke amp; Cole. And Man U is probably the biggest club in the prem. On the other hand you have icons like Hernandez, Pires, Kluivert, Inzaghi, Shearer, Petit, Larsson, Overmars, Litmanen, Laudrup, Blanc, Owen, that were either *iconic* for a gimmick (Inzaghi being the least gifted good footballer in history), *iconic* regionally (Larsson, Hernandez, Litmanen, Blanc, Laudrup) or they were *iconic* in the Prem (Petit, Overmars, Pires, Owen). I get that they need to boost sales so they put players that entice local gamers in Mexico, Sweden, Finland, France; I get that their biggest market is the UK so you have so many undeserving prem players, but even so. They used the word icon cause its so ambiguous. Legend implies some skill, to be an icon is to simply be a remembered footballer. Roger Milla was a remembered footballer, and they'll probably put him in game in the future over a WC winner like Luca Toni because people remember the dancing over actual abilities. That and him being from Africa (don't remember the country).
On what grounds?

All those Icons deserve less of a place than any of the others I mentioned. I'm wondering when did you start watching football if you believe Petit gt;Falcao or Pires gt;Conti, Overmars gt;Cafu. Or Litmanen gt;Totti or Shearer gt;Batistuta. Or Inzaghi gt;Voeller. I can go on but honestly if you think these "Roma guys are irrelevant" then - and bro I'm not trying to be condescending or patronizing - we have different opinions and there's really nothing to do about it.

Pires gt; Conti is absurd. Conti won the WC and was undoubtedly the best player of the entire tournament, even Paolo Rossi who won the Balon d'Or told him "they gave me this because I scored goals and you did the assists, but you deserve it". Conti was both a club legend nearly bringing a smaller club like Roma to win the CL back when to qualify you had to win the League and noy just place top 4. Pires was an amazing player don't get me wrong, but not even close. I think you can compare Overmars to Cafu since one was a RM and the other also played LM (even though he did mostly play LW and LF). Falcao was probably one of the greatest Center mids in the world in his prime, combining pace and dribbling and passing, he was very similair to Iniesta nowadays. Petit again, good but not best in his time. But again, they were very different times and a different football the 80s vs the 2000s, so I get that the debate is pointless and a matter of opinions. But cba with the Shearer gt;Batistuta, thats just not true. Batistuta is second only to Messi in goals for a big national team like Argentina, the guy was a tank mostly for Fiorentina but still managed to win one of 3 scudettos for Roma. Like both on the iconic and the skill he wins big time over Shearer. Shearer is a club legend for Blackburn and NUFC but honestly not much other than that. He was an immense player don't get me wrong especially in the prem but to place him on the same level as Batigol is absurd. Ask anybody in Italy, no matter the team if Roma Lazio Fiorentina Juventus Inter, and Batistuta is probably second only to Ronaldo if not on par with R9 as best striker in Serie A history.
Tl;dr different opinions

I'm saying that there are icons that deserve it more, not that he doesn't. That rather than have three Shearers, it would have made more sense to have one Shearer, one Batistuta and one Voeller for example.
Iniesta Raul and Romario have never played with either Best, Totti or Cantona. I'm just saying they deserve it more. Is it insane?

To each their own. Beckenbauer has my utmost respect, but the 90s had so many good offensive midfielders. Baggio and Del Piero, Gullit, Rivaldo, Figo, Zidane. That's why I still rate Laudrup, and I still believe he deserves an Icon, just not three of em if it's keeping out other Icons that imo are more deserving.

What proof do you have it doesn't exist? Edit: I got so much hate, I'll clarify. Since 100% of the people I know that play Fifa have experienced it in some way, shape, or form, having experienced it on my skin basically every game, knowing EA is a company known for its lack of transparency, knowing it's in their best interest to make games unpredictable and limit the skill gap, I am 100% sure that in some way shape or form games are piloted. I don't mean that there's active sliders, but rather, for example, that stamina/form affects teams differently. Yesterday I tied an absurd game 9-9. If I manage to upload it you'll clearly see my players running like crazy in the space and not missing a pass while we were tied 7-7, taking me up by two 9-7, and then in 2 half ET completely falling asleep, running at half the speed and missing every pass while his players did the exact opposite. I'm saying there must be some dynamic factor, like stamina or morale, that rather than depleting steadily shifts throughout the game.

The reasoning is simple; if you really want to play with them, and by really I mean REALLY, just by doing Squad Battles and Fut Champions every week, at an average level (Elite 3 and Gold 3) you'd have gained by now about 1.5 million ish. I don't agree 100% with the model, imo you should at least be able, with effort, to sport 2 top tier icons by now, but I realize that not being a pro and not buying packs makes it impossible; I think they should up SB rewards and pack luck, but knowing how greedy they are this current model maximizes their profit and they'd never change it. Again, morally I don't 100% agree with them, because imo in theory the only difference it should make to afford great teams is time, so ideally buying packs should get you to endgame quicker whereas not spending a dime should in the end still let you manage to afford a great team by the end of Fifa 18. But at the same time affording one of those players you listed, by grinding indefinetely, as of right now is possible even being f2p.

I don't know if you've ever played Dokkan Battle, but instead of packs with every player they have "banners" or categories of packs. This could be done in Fifa, eliminating normal packs and having, for example, an "Argentine UEFA Banner" where you can only get european players from Argentina, with a featured section of 10 cards (usually one good card, two decent cards and the rest are pretty shit) and an unfeatured section with every other argentinian player. So using this example, the banner would have Messi as the banner card at a 1% pull rate, Otamendi Dybala Higuain Di Maria Aguero Lanzini Gomez Biglia Fazio also each at a 1% pull rate, and a 90% rate of pulling any other Argentine playing in europe. So for example, it's true that you'd be tightening the pool, but at the same time you'd keep buying packs just to get Messi, cause the rest is pretty bad. Plus, they could add LRs like in Dokkan with Icons, so in the Argentine banner you'd have like a 0.3 chance of pulling Crespo or Maradona. And this can be done with IF banners, TOTS and TOTY, MOTM etc. So you can see the % of pulling each player in the banner.

I think the word "magic" is used because nanotech of that proportion is thousands of years away. I'm not saying we have the technology to create the Iron Man suit seen in the first movie right now, but the broad concepts behind it (propulsors, rockets, machine guns, holographic HUD, etc.) are somewhat tangible. The only "missing" thing is a reactor as powerful and small as the one in Tonys chest. But again, that "looks" (literally, on the screen) more believable to an average viewer than nanotech assembling instantenously at will to form a cannon.

Wait I agree completely but I think you're confusing fans woth average movie goers. Like of course I'm a marvel fan and if I'm willing to believe that Thanos spoke to a floating Red Skull, threw his adoptive green daughter down a cliff to obtain a stone he then places in a golden gauntlet making him super powerful I'm also willing to believe Tony made a scientific breakthrough. But people who go see the movie cause they enjoy the franchise from a distance will be like "that kind of technology looks like magic ugh" and I can't blame them cause at the end of the day they're not immersed in the movie universe and only compare what they see to real life examples. So Tonys nanotech in the MCU is super believable, whereas in the real world it would be revolutionary. Whereas his first suits, in the real world, would be an improvement but nowhere near groundbreaking.

I am going to clarify what I meant with a single comment that addresses all of the issues raised by you guys. My previous comment was referring to the OPs statement regarding "Unregular players", and not timed finishing in and of itself contributing to augmenting the skill gap. I was referring more to the OP when he argued Fifa should safeguard unregular players (as if it doesn't do that enough already). When it comes to timed finishing, there's certain flaws in your arguments. I would like to point out I'm exclusively talking about *first time timed finesses from outside of the box* as those seem to be the most effective and the least realistic, so don't take into consideration timed long shots or timed finesses with players already in control of the ball. So when it comes to these kinds of shots, personally I don't see how they are "broken". I agree that they are extremely unrealistic and make the game appear more random, but judging solely by personal experience, the only players to regularly pull off these shots once or more per game are pros. I've played every but one weekend league this year, and rarely did I encounter people spamming the combo, and never did I meat anyone particularly effective at it. I'm a big fan of the franchise as a whole, but I'm also one of its biggest critics when it comes to gameplay, but I enjoy regularly watching pros going at it. And therefore, watching Prinsipe or DhTekkz (did you guys know he recently turned 17?) I see them scoring insane bangers with this, so obviously I try to replicate it. You want to know my results at it? I have a hard time getting in position for the shot itself, so I barely manage those kinds of combinations per game, and even when I get the pass timed just right I need to time the impact of the second shot just right. It's not uncommon to hit red or yellow, so that's still not incredibly easy, and only the more careful and dedicated users will master it. So lets say you hit a green timed finesse combo; for the player to score that first-time timed finesse I have to get lucky they're on their good foot; you wouldn't be able to count how many of these shots my IF Mbappe sent to Mars with his left foot. If you watch pros of course you'd think its a broken combo, cause they are the best at creating these situations, they're the best at timing these shots, and of course have the best icons which are suited for the job, but that sh*t won't work with everything for everyone, trust me. I'm a gold 1 player so of course I'm not the best but I'm still slightly above average I'd say, and after 500 games I still have to meet a non-pro who has mastered this shot to the point where he can score two or more of these per game. Thing is, and this must come as no offense, as soon as people concede even one of these in a whole weekend league, they're gonna start bitching and whining about it, and that's the biggest issue with this game. If people complained less they'd keep this game more enjoyable, but constant complaining brings the Devs to edit gameplay every other week, making it always less enjoyable. Now I know most of my evidence is anecdotal, so don't get too rattled about it please. Thx and good luck this weekend.

Anecdotal evidence, I fear, can hardly be called evidence at all. You cannot cite your experience as proof, because it's quite subjective. I'll give you an example; with a fairly cheap meta team costing less then a million featuring Son, Salah and Aubameyang as its best players, Andy Robertson and Davinson Sanchez being the worse, I reached Gold 2 fairly consistently getting very close to Gold 1 most of those times. Couple of weeks ago guaranteed IF packs showed up, got lucky and made 1.5 million pulling Mbappe and Hazard. I make a team with Neymar, 87 Crespo, IF Mbappe, Pogba, Ramos, Varane, IF Depay... etc. changing my squad mid weekend league. I was again getting close to Gold 1 before making the switch, but after the switch those last 10 games were a struggle; yet I made Gold 2 again. I thought I needed to get used to the team so I didn't worry. This weekend starting the full WL with this team I start off really really well, with an 11-4. I thought Gold 1 was near. The next 15 games were catastrophic, I barely won 5 of those 15 games left. Ended up short of Gold 2. And it's not that I don't click with this team, I actually play so much better with them. It's just that so many things are taken into factor with matchmaking and gameplay with these teams. Take into factor handicap, take into factor momentum shifts and scripted gameplay etc. Luck too. You may be the exception to the rule, but overall Gold 3 people with bad teams don't turn into Gorilla if you give them R9, trust me.

I reread Book 6 and 7 this past week, and I realized one thing. Despite Molly killing Bellatrix being a really monumental and cult scene in our childhoods, I would have loved for Bellatrix to die at the hands of... *Kreacher.* Honestly so many reasons why it would have been a much richer and more symbolic scene, and most are obvious, but I'll list them anyway. 1. First and foremost giving Kreachers presence in the final battle more meaning, a more specific and concrete contribution, since he wanted to avenge Master Regulus this would have given him a tangible hero moment. 2. For House elves in general. This would not have been Kreachers main motivation, but would have still been so inspiring for a House Elf to kill one of the main exponents of the "Wizard nazi party". Their filosophy being about "pure bloods" and anti-muggles. Imagine a house elf defying one of the strongest death eaters, and then killing her. 3. For Dobby. They were never friends, sure, but they did work together in tailing Malfoy in Half Blood Prince, and in general for Dobby to be avenged by another House Elf would have come full circle. 4. For Sirius. Sirius was still the last Black alive, and Kreachers last master. And Kreacher never sounds "happy" about Sirius being dead. Maybe his love for Regulus brings him to want to avenge the brother that looked so much like his master. And killing her, the treacherous woman that burnt off the last branch of the Black family tree, would definetely give great purpose to Kreacher. Point is, it would be cooler for Sirius to be avenged by Kreacher, since this would also signify redemption for Kreachers betrayal of Sirius in Order. 5. For Hermione. Tortured by Bellatrix for her blood status, a girl that always fought for House Elves with S.P.E.W etc., think about her face seeing a house elf finally in the spotlight, gaining the attention and admiration she always thought his race deserved. 6. For Harry. Harry has numerous times shown in the series how much he despises Bellatrix. She tortured Nevilles parents, she kills Sirius and Dobby, she tortures Hermione, she nearly kills Ginny. Since Kreacher is still "property" of Harry Potter at the time (supposing he was later freed) what better last act of subservience to Harry would it have been to be the extension of Harrys person and do what Harry longed for, which was for Bellatrix to suffer a dysmal fate? 7. When Bellatrix dies, Voldemort is profoundly shaken. He is seen halting his duel with Kingsley, Slughorn and McGonagall out of pure rage for losing his most faithful lieutenant. How cool would it have been for Voldemort to turn around and see the house elf he thought dead holding a replica of his horcrux around his neck? The creature he believed worthless and expendable fighting, beating, killing even his number one servant? The elven magic he always overlooked and underestimated and despised triumphing over the Dark magic he believed unbeatable?
Tbh this year its overall the most enjoyable mode so you'll probably be happier doing this than Squad Battles or Division Rivals

Despite the fact that there's actually a lot of evidence supporting the theory that scripting exists, 99% of it is anecdotal, with most of it consisting of people saying, "I was up 4-0 and then my players stopped playing". I trust people when they tell me this because I lived it on my own skin, but it's still weak evidence, being so unsubstantial. On the other hand there is a lot of hard evidence proving there is no scripting, most of it in the codes and in first hand testimonies from the devs. The right question that should be asked would regard pros and cons for EA to include momentum, script and handicap in their codes. How would EA benefit? The possibilities are endless. Selling Fifa points to addicted users who falsely believe an upgrade in their team ("If I had X instead of Y at right back I wouldn't have conceded that goal") would have changed the outcome. Being more friendly to casual users too. People who can't grind Rank 1 - Gold 1 and therefore have under 400k teams. How could they ever beat someone who has 5 icons and plays everyday? Handicap and momentum'll do the job. On the other hand, would they run into issues if these elements were discovered? What are the cons for them to include these mechanics in-game? I'd say none. Most of the people I know, most of the youtubers and most of the pros don't even doubt this fact, they take it for granted that the game presents these mechanics. Yet they never falter in playing the game despite the fact they would bet their lives on the existence of momentum. So what can you gain from this? That being *sure* about the presence of these mechanics is maybe going a bit too far, but surely don't blindly believe what EA tells you. It probably exists and is being impressively hidden, but never be sure about anything.

I played around 100 games with him. Decent pace, great shooting, great passing and surprising dribbling. Can only play CAM in a 4 2 3 1 (not RAM or LAM). If you just need a good icon that is a bit more versatile look elsewhere. If you need a good CAM icon he's great cost-efficiency wise.

Ok so the reason why I have an issue with time travel in movies is exactly portrayed in this movie. As soon as I saw it I believed it to be a great and untouchable movie but sitting back and thinking about it, I realized how many plotholes time travel generates. It seems to me as rather than choosing one "time travel trope", Endgame incorporated all of them. Cap going back in the past and showing up old at Tony's funeral is a clear example of Novikov's self consistency principle (too lazy to explain it, look it up), but Tony snapping / killing the Thanos of 2014 and it not affecting their timeline is a clear example of the distinct diverging timeline trope. So whereas Cap staying in the past affects the current timeline, Thanos dying does not.

So last year Zoey Saldana called the movie "Gauntlet". We later found out that wasn't true, but I think that at the time it was, and later changed. Watching Endgame it makes sense why they wanted to call it Avengers: Infinity Gauntlet; the word Gauntlet obviously means a medieval army glove, which is what they are trying to obtain, but it also means "ordeal", which is what they go through with the time heist. This definition in particular derives from the saying of "running the gauntlet", a military tradition of running through lines of soldiers while getting attacked, which is what our heroes do in the gauntlet relay race during the final battle. Thought it was a neat easter egg.
Why dragonball???
This is clearly bs. This would mean Thanos now knows how everything plays out during the events of IW. I don't think he would repeat the same mistakes.
Unless of course you suppose that Tony factored this in and in his snap willed Thanos to forget everything that happened, but even that is a stretch.

Imagine time as a rubber band. It does its best to keep its original form until it reaches its elastic limit; surpassing it leads to its rupture point. This is from my 10th grade physics class so take it with a grain of salt. Evidently Cap going back to lead a quiet life with Peggy was so insignificant that it just slightly pulled on the rubber band of time, deforming it maybe but not breaking it. Therefore he did not generate a new timeline but rather conformed to the current one, because the two distinct timelines (events up to Endgame and the one Cap returned to) were compatible in most; therefore they merged. This of course means that Cap, despite knowing the future course of events, willingly laid low (didn't stop JFKs assassination, or Howards, or didn't warn anybody about Thanos). Definetely a stretch but supposing all of this, it is possible that a quiet life with Peggy would have not affected the future significantly (again, this means that we don't account for the butterfly affect either). 2014 Thanos dying on the other hand was such a turning point in history that it split off the timeline, generating a second one. It was such a strong yank on the rubber band that it ripped it and created a different ramification. In theory, taking all of this as possible, as of right now, there's two distinct timelines, one in which Thanos disappeared in 2014 and the guardians may have formed and fought Ronan, but without Thanos and Nebula in the picture, and the second main one that we saw with Endgame. A third possible one may have formed with Loki disappearing but I suppose Cap stopped him when he went to return the Time and Mind stones back. So two timelines for sure, maybe more.

Ofc but they're told some things obviously and maybe the provisional title was Infinity Gauntlet while they decided which one to go with definetely and it slipped. Why would she let it slip otherwise?

Time travel in movies sucks, no way around it, because time travel is theorized in different forms following different physics theories. So at the end of the day you have to try and rationalize what the movie tells you. It's a bummer but time travel is a sticky subject. The movie was amazing regardless.
Bucky as shown in Infinity War is tired of fighting and is looking to rest and eat his plums. He's not a fighter anymore; Sam is.

But what if the story of the first 22 movies of the MCU isn't from the main timeline? What if this is Branch Timeline 5, and the events in that timeline played out similairly to the MT, meaning they fight Thanos and Tony dies, the only prerogatives to Steve showing up on that bench? What if Cap, going back to the 50s and living with Peggy was very careful with his actions, and his influence on that timeline was quite conservative. Maybe in the main timeline our heroes defeat Thanos in a slightly different way; maybe Thor dies along with Tony. Maybe Ant Man is a woman. Point is, nobody told you that old Steve originates from this timeline. People are castrated by the idea that Cap must have lived out his life in a different timeline from the main one shown in the MCU, and somehow traveled back to this "main timeline", not considering the idea that this timeline we see is not the original main one.

If Cap in Avengers (2012) is biologically 25, and in Endgame is 36, and he returns to Peggy around 1950, this means the old Cap we meet on the bench is 109. It would make sense for the Super soldier serum to slow down ageing but god he looks barely 70.

This was my theory initially, but overall knowing Steve he would never stand by and be passive about injustice. So maybe he wouldn't stop Howard Starks assassination or save Bucky because otherwise he might interfere with Tony being Iron Man and ultimately saving the day, but I'm confident he would have warned them in 2017 about Thanos somehow. Maybe telling them not to send Nebula to Morag in 2014. My point is that the Avengers could have won in Endgame without Tony dying, so I'm sure Steve would have warned them, ultimately because it would have created an alternate timeline with a happy and well Tony, why not give it a shot?

If they work in 'sagas' and then 'phases', I don't think Galactus or Doom will be the bad guys in the next Avengers movie. Firstly because it'll be a while before they focus on the newly acquired properties, treading lightly because both X-men and F4 have had recent movies. I don't believe anything before 2022 will regard the new franchises. I'd say phase 4 will regard the current Earth Avengers (especially Spider-man, Doctor Strange, Black Panther, Falcon, Ant Man {and the Wasp} and Scarlet Witch) coming to terms with the fact that they carry the responsibility of defending Earth now that all 6 og avengers have moved on in different ways (and I think it's already pretty evident with FFH and Spidey saying Earth needs a new Iron Man). All of those individual movies will culminate in a 'New Avengers' movie which will have the same vibe the original Avengers movie carries - with the Heroes building their chemistry and learning to work together against a more Earth bound threat. Maybe Hulk or Rhodey act as the Fury of the situation. The X men and the F4 will have solo movies later on that - in a similar fashion to how GOTG really established Thanos and the Stones (elements that were only introduced or hinted at in earlier movies) - establish new villains and new elements (like Galactus, Doom, Apocalypse) and only in the big, final, saga-wrapping movie a-la Endgame will we see them all team up. The MCU always works in a very organic manner; heroes are never just dropped in conveniently for the plot. The GOTG were slowly eased into the greater saga, so I guess that's what's gonna happen for the Fox franchises as well.

Swaps is an awful idea

Ok so bear with me a second; the Fut community can be summarized in three general socio economic layers; 1. The upper elite class, made up of Youtubers, Pros, and people who spend #8364;1000+ a year on the game. 2. The middle-lower working class, meaning people that either do buy some Fifa points around TOTY but where their spending is nowhere near enough to tilt the balance of the game, or people who spend no money at all but play every weekend league and achieve Gold 1 ish rewards along with Div 3/4 Rank II rewards each week. 3. The casuals, the ones that can only play the game two/three times a week, that barely have the time to play Weekend League, or that are just not good enough and don't get decent rewards. Tier 1 obviously has no need for swaps; they sit on so much money (teams over 5 mil) that the grind for swaps is just not worth it. The cards are nowhere good enough for them to go out of their way trying to get them. Why would I grind 23 tokens for Essien when I'm sitting on 5 mil to buy 90 Gullit? The cards are nowhere good enough to warrant that grind. Tier 2 is where most of us belong. This class comprises all of my friends as well as myself and most redditors, and constitutes the core of the game. These are the players EA should cater to. We are the players that have the time, the energy, the love of the game as well as the necessity to grind free icons, because despite how much time we put into the game even baby Eusebio is just a dream for most of us. Is the swap system better than last year's for this group of users? Hell no. The quality of the icons is piss poor, nowhere near what we could afford through SBCs last year around the same period of time. They're all pretty mediocre, none of them are endgame and the few that are warrant a disproportionate amount of effort and time. Why should I grind 23 tokens for baby Vieira when futmas Sissoko cost me less than 200 k through his SBC? Last year you could aspire to get pro level icons through SBCs thanks to icon crafting. Sure, you couldn't get all of them but if you really loved Eusebio or Cruyff you knew you could at least grind his SBC, grind upgrades, take untradeable rewards in Rivals. Now those cards are unaffordable, and instead the top you can aspire to is mid ADP or baby Dinho. Tier 3 is of course casuals or players with little time or ability. Keep that in mind cause I'm going to come back to that in a second. Why was the swaps system implemented? The "official" version was simple: making icons affordable for everybody. Well, lets analyze it tier by tier. Tier 3, guess what; not only is the swaps system non affordable for casuals (which as I said not only would they need first owner cards, which they don't have nearly enough of, but they'd have to win games in Rivals, where they don't have nearly enough skill, or Squad Battles, which they don't have enough time for). I'm also gonna add, some friends who joined Fifa 19 late last year, who only played FOUR weekend leagues, and by may could still boast moments Bergkamp AND moments Desailly by completeing their SBCs. That's something that's almost impossible now for someone buying Fifa today. Tier 2; good icons are now LESS affordable. If I want Cruyff I need coins, because best case scenario his swap (most likely his baby version) will become available in May. So if I want his baby version I'm gonna probably have to wait for May, whereas last year through saving and grinding I got his Prime Moment SBC done in the first week of April. Tier 1; again, why would they do swap challenges when they can buy that card on the market? Do you see Castro, or MattHDgamer, or Pros like Tekkz or semi ex pros like Kurt doing swaps??? Now the core of the question; why then, why did they implement swaps and take away SBCs? It's obvious isn't it, it was costing them money. Fifa 19, despite being one of the worst gameplay wise, was arguably the best content wise. It allowed players to icon craft, avoiding buying Fifa points. Through the sbc system a player with NO real money spending on the game and decent results in weekend league (Gold 1) could afford to complete Eusebio and Vieira like my friend, or prime Ronaldinho and moments Cruyff like myself. It was a great way because that meant grinding, but a healthy grind, a grind that was worth it. This new grind is unhealthy and sick; it incentivizes keeping cards rather than selling them ("I better not sell this Griezmann, he might come in handy for LaLiga first owner challenges"), stalling the economy, but even worse it incentivizes buying Fifa Points, cause guess what, cards out of packs are first owner items. This was a really long comment but that -5 didn't sit well with me so I had to explain myself. Tl;dr icon swaps are the umpteenth time EA pull a money grab to bump their revenue. The SBC system was better and needed no fixing, and was removed solely because it cost them money.

"Drawbacks" should be really called limits since they're something that can be overcome through training. All Might has no issues with his quirk, Mirio overcame every drawback to his quirk through training, hypothetically even Aizawa could find a solution to having to blink. Obviously the point of drawbacks is to avoid characters being One-Punch level OP, so Eraserhead has to blink, but theoretically he could have something in his glasses installed to hydrate his eyes and he would be virtually unstoppable. I imagine wings would have the natural drawback of not being strong enough to lift you initially, only useful as an attack limb, but with the right training they'd become strong enough to carry you for progressively longer periods of time before being tired.

I found him (untradeable gold upgrade yeah I know MAD) and tbh he's good-ish. I replaced my Futmas Sissoko with him playing him CM with a shadow card in a flat 442 near walmart Gullit. My play-style tries to be an emulation of the maltese GOAT (free my boy Kurt) so I push Gullit forward while my other CM, Marcelo, is on Stay back while attacking, so even though it's a 442 it plays as a 41212. Sorry for the boring premise but if you're gonna play him CDM in a 4231 it's going to be a very different experience compared to mine so I wanted to give you a heads up in case my opinion could be useless. So; compared to Sissoko he's almost on par defensively but nowhere even in the same ballpark as strong physically. He's A LOT faster (obviously) and much better on the ball though, so once you win the ball back the transition for the counterattack is quick, smooth and fluid. He's also a better dribbler and better passer than Sissoko. I still think he's better in the other CM position, with less responsibilities defensively and more attacking freedom, but I can't change Gullit, even the Walmart version. As a pure CDM he sometimes struggles to outmuscle opponents, and he's only 174 cm which is a nuisance sometimes. Overall I'm happy because I'd rather risk the defensive issues and have another asset offensively, plus the 5* skills are fun for me cause I tend to skill a bit, but if you already struggle defensively and need a purebred CDM I'd go with David Luiz SS if you manage to fit him with chem. I tried his card and he's insane in that position. He's a juiced up Sissoko. Wins everything and is all over the place. Seeing as you played Kroos though I think Marcelo might be a very strong upgrade, they're similar but Marcelo is better in almost everything. Keep Partey though.

And not just that, but even taking those aspects out, if Bakugo really thought he was perfect he wouldn't work as hard to surpass All Might; if he really believed himself to be perfect he would feel stronger than All Might already. Bakugo is a really noble character in a twisted way. His quirk is good, maybe great, but what he does with it is amazing. He works extremely hard because he knows he can be the best; he doesn't think that he's perfect, but he tries to be. I'd also add that even though western culture avoids recognizing it in media, personal attachments to people, friends and lovers, are sometimes an obstacle. Bakugo doesn't want people getting in his way. He doesn't want to lose friends on the battlefield, he doesn't want to be distracted by loved ones, etc. I think he would want to be the one protecting and saving people so bad that he even hates being protected and saved. And look, even though All Might is a nice guy he shut everybody out too, from Sir Nighteye to Gran Torino to David Shield. Endeavor did it in an even worse way with his family. Nana Shimura did it with her son too. I think the message Horikoshi tries to convey is that being a hero is a solitary road, and Bakugo is the most aware of it.

First off, Kirishima's relationship with Bakugo is a weird one. He's also abused by Bakugo but whereas others tend to give Katsuli space when he gets angry/abusive, Kirishima always just laughs it off. I think it must somewhat relate to his quirk; Kirishimas unbreakable and relentless, not only physically but mentally too. Plus, I think he's the only one seeing through Bakugos act. But never in the wholo series does Bakugo acknowledge him as a friend. Bakugo does respect Kirishima the most, and that relationship is arguably the one that's gonna affect Bakugo the most during the series. Secondly, stop acting as if it's the first antihero you've ever seen in media. He's a cool character and gives depth to the society. Some want to be the number 1 hero to help people, like All Might and Izuku, some want to be number 1 because of pettiness, like Endeavor no longer wanting to be number 2 and Shoto to surpass his father. Hell, some want to be heroes just to have a harem like Mineta lol. And finally some want to be number 1 for the sake of being number 1, that's it. And Bakugo, because he knows how relationships get in the way, people get in the way, just pushes everyone away to reach his goal, but even then there are moments where he is a decent human being. Bakugo isn't a villain, at most he's an antihero, but to me he's a hero with a lot of depth and growth over the series; there's a lot of interesting aspects that sometimes make him more entertaining than Izuku and his sometimes cliche bland motivations.

Premises being made that you're extremely standoffish for no reason lol, and also that Bakugo doesn't need to say it for the author to intend it, as actions are a much better form of literary exposition than words; an example is when he's kidnapped by the LoV he explicitly tells Deku not to come save him. Obviously you're gonna see it as pride or him being a dick somehow cause #hateonKacchan2020 but to me he doesn't want Deku or anybody getting hurt saving him. And again when he gets saved by grabbing Kirishimas hand I imagine you're going to argue that he's friends with Kirishima and that's why he did it, but I think he was happy his "friends" came for him in the end even though he was scared for them.

I think it also relates to Horikoshi growing as a writer. In the beginning his characters were too extreme and radical; Bakugo was borderline psychopathic and sadistic, Izuku could have replaced Mother Theresa for how excessively nice and idealistic he was to everyone all the time. Whereas now, especially in the manga, Deku is growing more competitive to a healthy degree, and Bakugo is more of a loner than an outright dick (his insults are much lighter and used as comic relief than his initial downright abusive ways of speaking to people). They're never going to meet in the middle, Bakugo is always gonna be much more self centered than Deku and Deku is always going to put others before himself, but the former is warming up to his classmates' presence and the latter finally stopped crying when people looked at him wrong, so I guess it's a nice developing dynamic. And honestly who's shining through this is Shoto; he's apathetic and minds his own business most of the time like Bakugo but is still super polite to everyone without ever being mean gratuitiously, and he makes it his mission to unselfishly save people without being cheesy or corny like Deku.

gt;so its a headcanon. My guy why are you so stuck up with this headcanon bs. If a character behaves in a certain way, his actions are meant to be interpreted deeper than face value. Literally every english class I took in my life was analyzing the deeper meanings of words. Why can't you go deeper than what he does to why he does it? Do you think Horikoshi would write up a lot of differently motivated conflicted characters, like Endeavor, Shoto (their family issues), Deku (his desire to save people came from the sense of inadequacy he felt when quirkless), Ochaco (poverty), Iida (responsability), and then go ahead and write up a central character like Bakugo who's only role is to be a two dimensional dick? Of course there must be deeper motivations to be explored. To be interpreted ffs. gt;Bakugou challenges Midoriya for their second fight And the only reason he did was to self punish himself for the guilt he felt over All Mights loss of his powers. He felt like he was the end of the symbol of peace. He thought it was his fault All Might lost his powers. That alone is an example of his depth. If he was so self centered as you love to describe him, if his view of the world was so Darwinian where the survival of the fittest prevailed, a dog-eat-dog world, he would have shrugged it off as "All Mights weaker than I thought, meh". Instead he actually feels guilty and troubled about the whole ordeal because there's a part of him that cares much more than how you make him out to be.

Despite the fact that this is a good theory and a nice twist, I think Hori leans towards a "anybody, even someone born without powers, can be a hero" avoiding the destiny bs etc. The point is anybody can be exceptional, even those born ordinary, so Deku born with amazing mad powers kinda defeats the purpose and drags BNHA into the "this was my destiny all along" territory that in the history of shonens got boring quick.

I don't disagree with what you say but it still would give Deku a central role in AfOs story, something I'd dislike. Deku is a nobody that through who he is as a person, and not as a hero, is granted awesome power; having held a very strong power before the beginning of the story 'qualifies' him in a way I don't think we need. Up to now I wasn't disappointed with Hori's storytelling so all in all if he decides to go that way I'm sure it won't stick out as a sore thumb and it will be able to add a new layer to the story without falling into dumb cliches. So I'm not against it at all and wouldn't be mad if he adds that layer, and I'd even be excited to see that story told, but as of right now I think he's going in the quirkless direction.

Well tbh Deku is never really a chosen one-esque kind of character. gt;!It's stated over and over how All Might, despite going from quirkless to OfA user, didn't have any issues learning or adapting to the quirk. He didn't break any bones and he fairly quickly became the symbol of peace. Mirio is another example of a character who is implied to be better suited for the power. But the point is Deku through sheer power of will, hard headedness and perseverance will become the strongest hero of all time despite the fact that he's starting the race way behind others. He is chosen in the sense that All Might sees in him hero material without the powers, and this in a way serves as an example to the viewers that anybody can be a hero.! lt; If you drop a chosen one storyline all it does is dilute that message imo.

I find your comment a welcome breath of fresh air just by how nice and polite it is, I'm not used to it on the internet right now, cheers. Anyway, yeah, shonens are formulaic, it's basically in the definition of what makes them shonens. The point is bnha wasn't always a standard shonen, that's what got me into reading it (the same way I imagine it hooked you). It thrives on pioneering certain things in this genre; "My Villain Academia", for example, or the protagonist not being that OP compared to other run-of-the-mill shonens. These are a couple of examples of territories no other shonen manga explored before. Power scaling isn't of itself bad, the issue with it is when it isn't organic. Shiggy in MVA was organic, and to a certain extent his latest "update" is too, but its justified for people to fear what might happen now. To imagine Deku (or hypothetically Endeavor) having a similar power up would be too much of a deus ex machina and make this manga too similair to a DBZ of sorts. I fear what will happen is someone is going to die, triggering Deku into getting a big power up in proportion to Shiggys but honestly that would be inorganic; Deku has slowly progressed into a stronger more confident hero, even discovering new powers. He had instances of brilliance like vs. Overhaul, but even then it was for a short instance and with help from Eri. What would be organic is for him to grow at his pace, not to have a surprisingly-well-timed unsolicited random 'awakening'. I have a feeling though that Horikoshi won't necessarily go in that direction, but will add a plot twist that makes either the villains win (a-la Infinity War/Empire Strikes Back ending), or Shigaraki fucking it up for himself rather than outright losing. Tl;dr: I don't think people have issues with what's happening now, but have issues with what might happen at the end of the path Horikoshi is currently taking us.

Pulling a DBZ would be ditching Bakugo and Todoroki too. I'd be fine if he saved at least those two from the oblivion of forgotten manga characters. I wake up at night, sweating, screaming from the nightmares caused by imagining Todoroki and Bakugo as Piccolo and Vegeta.

It takes a lot of movie tropes from western literature, like the whole superhero theme. Also until now it didn't really see Deku just receiving a power up every time he needed it out of sheer coincidence the same way for example Goku would. Also, Deku is the obvious protagonist but until now it's not like he's left everyone else behind in terms of powers and abilities, despite the fact that his potential is way higher. Deku loses more times than I can remember and when he wins he wins at an enormous cost physically. Another thing that separates it from a Naruto or a DBZ is that there is no predestination to Dekus story. He isn't born a chosen one, and only his actions define who he is along the story. He earns All Mights respect and thus his power, he is born as powerless as can be. And when he gets his powers which in theory are supposed to be the best he is miles behind his classmates. Another thing I noticed is that the story of itself is way more fleshed out, less formulaic. It has a really big main cast; not just heroes, but villains too, and they aren't your run of the mill bad guys that just want power. They have character development, whereas in the few other shonens I can think of villains are usually two dimensional plot devices. By this I'm not saying bnha is a superior product, cause tbh I like my fair share of fanservice and you don't really get shit like Gogeta or Vegito here, and I really enjoy that stuff. But at the same time it makes it less predictable, making it a completely different experience that after years of the same stuff is a nice change of pace.

Meh, I'd argue the bad guy ultimately wins in Civil War, which I guess you didn't bring up, but to an extent the good guys don't win in Endgame either. Tony's dead, Nat is dead, Clint is depressed cause Nat's dead, Steve lost Tony and Nat and lived 5 years without Bucky or Sam, now Sam is alive but he doesn't feel at home anymore in 2023 and Bucky is a weird dude, Gamora is a different Gamora, Thor is fat and suffers from ptsd, Scott missed out on some of the best years with his daughter, Vision died and Wanda lost Vision (for now), Peter lost the closest thing to a father figure since uncle Ben and that caused some issues later on, I mean the list is really long and I could go on. Thanos didn't win but the good guys didn't either, ultimately the great winner is Zemo since his plan came to fruition in 2023.

I don't think Rick is a bad father, though both Beths and many people in this discussion keep pointing out. He was a bad father but tried fixing it; he realizes he did huge damage on Beth by leaving and so knows Beth is fucked up because of him. He loves Beth and wants the time he missed out on with her back, but realizes he can't selfishly keep her with him because that'll just lead her in constantly seeking his approval. So he makes a perfect clone which lets face it in Ricks nihilistic view means he has two daughters now, and allows one to seek that independence and that adventure, while the other can stay with Jerry and be a loving mother. At the end of the day Beth managed to do something we all wish we could do, which is live multiple lives at the same time.
To me he's letting Beth have her cake and eat it too. It's easy to love Rick and it's hard to hate Rick, but it's REALLY hard to understand Rick imo.
If Shiggy steals Aizawas quirk I wouldn't be surprised if his final clash with Deku sees him deactivate Dekus powers and Deku managing to beat him quirk free the same way he was born.

This is the first time I play a 2k game since I've never been into basketball this much. I liked the sport, I always knew who won and the best players and watched some big games and dunk contests and the finals but being from Italy I always preferred football (or soccer as you call it) and would always play Fifa except for the odd free 2k game on the store in late July. With that #8364;5 promo that came out around May I bought the game and I found it light years ahead of Fifa. You guys are incredibly lucky compared to us. I never really played basketball that much so I know I'll never fully understand how the gameplay behaves compared to real life but it's still 400 times more realistic than Fifa. The rosters are so much deeper when it comes to legends with 2k having basically almost every half decent player that played in the NBA except for the occasional Barkley or Miller. MyCareer cant even be compared to Fifas piss poor take of a career mode, don't even get me started; first of all it's so much more than a career because of the neighborhood features, allowing you to play classic career in the NBA, a "pro clubs" fac simile in pro am and a cool quick match with REC. Second of all you get to actually customize your player, you not only get to buy clothes and shoes and tattoos and emotes and jumpshots but have a shoe creator from scratch, whereas FIFA doesn't even allow you to customize beyond hair and facial features (but nowhere near as much as on 2k). MyTeam lacks competitive modes but is still incredibly fun albeit a cash grab, and reward players you can get by playing are SO much better than the Fifa ones. I mentioned gameplay, but beyond just how realistic it is there's nowhere near as many cheeses abused like in FIFA. I could go on, there's pretty much nothing Fifa does better except maybe Fut Champions, but if you feel like comparing I can add more examples. I know basketball is a smaller sport with only 30 teams compared to FIFA that has around 600, but I'd rather have a game that's dedicated to the top 8 leagues in Europe rather than have so much depth that dilutes the quality. So honestly don't complain as much, I for one will be buying 2k21 to disintoxicate myself from years of Fifa. 2k is a game that is flawed but its still probably the best sports game on the market rn.

Exactly! You can't hold the game to your unrealistic standard; the standard is set by every other game in the industry. You're out here complaining that hairstyles/hairlines are glitchy (?) meanwhile Fifa is a cashgrab that has only one mode (FUT) that is extremely poorly taken care of. You complain about AI? Have you ever seen what De Ridder or Schulz or Genereux do on pro clubs every day? Sit back and be thankful of what you have while we're out here begging EA to give us a decent game. Tbh I saw a big post replied with a big comment. Tl;dr: this particular 2k fan is complaining about "first world problems"

Every sports game ties its core mechanics to in-game currency, but in no game you can grind that currency like in 2k. An example would be the following: MyTeam 10 boxes cost around 100k vc right? In MyCareer an average player will make 100k vc in around 30-40-ish NBA games with incentives and endorsements and whatnot. Compare that to Fifa, where Fifa points can only be bought with real life currency. You could use the coins you use on the market (like NBAs MT), but its gonna take around 90 games for an average player to make 100k coins for a pack. And don't get me started on the packweight cause its not even funny how ridicolously Fifa packs yield compared to 2k. And how can you talk about microtransactions when in a mode like MyTeam they're not even as necessary, since in theory you could PLAY to get GOAT Kobe, GOAT Bird and Hakeem.

Terry Crews tried agreeing with you and he's getting canceled lmao. Reading your comment I can break it down in two points, the first being you taking up an issue with the silence of the political lib-left not distancing itself from these people, and the second with people like Iverson or Stephen Jackson and their relationship with the BLM movement. The first has a convoluted explanation. Today people put all of their focus on one goal at a time - or all of their eggs in one basket if you want to use a metaphor. It's as if today's society has an acute form of ADHD that they can't focus on more than one cause, and what happens with that is that they become blinded by a dogma. People don't form opinions anymore, they side with a generic ideal and allow the exponents advocating for that ideal to shape their opinion. Basically because of goddamn laziness people allow other people to think for themselves. People in the US since George Floyds tragic murder seem to have developed the idea that the African American struggle and police brutality are all of a sudden the number one most important issue. Fuck Covid, fuck the crippling poverty disparity that is at the base of racial injustice, fuck the lack of health care, fuck the failing education system, fuck the gender wage gap and sexism in general and the whole caravan of injustice agaibst women for centuries, fuck the opioid epidemic, fuck the LGBTQ+ struggle, fuck gun control, fuck foreign policy, fuck everything, drop everything that you're doing and get to chant for the defunding of the police (these are just the tip of the iceberg, the US is a fucked country, I'm sorry but I'll say what every European is thinking). There are so many blatant issues but now the most important one is this one, so a guy can be homophobic, sexist and antisemitic as long as he's not racist against african americans. I support BLM, I believe one should be antiracist, but I'm not as myopic as certain people that blatantly ignore other issues. An example of this would be the central park Karen incident a couple of weeks ago; the narrative imposed by the media and people in general was "racist white woman uses her privilege to call police on innocent black man". And yet, had it happened in the midst of the me too movement where the rave was female empowerment and not the George Floyd protests, the narrative would have been "Man uses his male privilege to threaten an innocent woman in the park". What transpired that day lives somewhere in the middle; that woman was wrong for calling the police but that man was covertly threatening her and him being a male allowed for that to happen. That woman completely freaked out and was pretty scared in that situation, and honestly I don't blame her. Alone in the park, you'd be scared if a man used the words "I'ma do something you won't like" - indipendent of the color of his skin. Her racism seeped when she used the police as a weapon, but you can't deny they were both (to different degrees of extent) in the wrong. So tl;dr the left won't take a stance to distance itself from racist black activists because right now the black struggle is the only issue that people care about and that'll bring in big votes come November. The second issue is of simpler explanation. BLM is doing mostly good, but since it has no actual coherent and cohesive positions on certain topics, certain people can end up appropriating and misconstruing the message. I still think black lives matter shouldn't be a movement; it should be a blanket statement everyone should agree with, like saying the sky is blue. To entertain the idea that it's an ideal or opinion, and not an irrefutable truth, empowers those that view it as something you can disagree with or object to (but I realize in todays world it had to be marketed in some outstanding way). But just because certain people like Stephen Jackson or AI say certain stuff and they gravitate around that movement shouldn't make you confuse the distinct situations arising. During the civil rights movement to support Dr. King didn't mean to support Malcolm and vice-versa. Just because the NOI or Louis Farrakhan or Allen Iverson want certain things doesn't mean BLM and those behind it with a pure heart and good intentions do too.

Cristiano Ronaldo is more of a Kobe with how much he's obsessed with being the best, it's really on another level. I would have said Jordan but MJ had this thing with winning rather being the best, so he was fine with other people taking important shots and having top players like Pip or Rodman with him. When the triangle was implemented his scoring went down but he didn't really care as long as he got to win. Kobe instead wanted to be the Alpha and struggled with Phil and Shaq the same way Ronaldo wants to constantly be the best in a primadonna fashion. And I'm not hating on either cause they were the best in their prime and have trophies to back it up. R9 Ronaldo is in a way similar to D Rose in the sense that he was the best for a short while but injuries slowed him down alot after a couple of great years. Iverson would be Ronaldinho in the sense that he was an incredibly entertaining fun player who had the efficiency to match that entertainment value but lacked the discipline to keep up that form. Stevie G is a bit of a Nowitzki in the sense that he stayed with one club and had his fair share of success but was way better than what his trophy cabinet can attest. Pele is easily comparable to Bill Russel. Both played ages ago in what could be considered a different sport, should be considered pioneers but are sometimes too hyped up because of how much they won. The extent of the Messi-Ronaldo rivalry can be associated to the Bird-Magic rivalry which made the sport entertaining again, and because of how they were on enemy teams and split the number of awards among them, but as players I don't see any similarities. Today I'd say Mbappe and Luka are similar in the sense that they are so young yet look so seasoned, and play like leaders and veterans. Zion burst in the scene as arrogantly and dominantly as Haland did, lets see if they keep it up. Giannis is so loveable and came out of nowhere that he reminds me of Ngolo Kante but he has a lot to win to show that. Lebron reminds me of Messi because of his nearly 20 year long dominance in the league and yet he's constantly questioned by haters bringing up stupid details like Lebron being 3-6 and Messi's lack of success with Argentina, as if they both weren't the best thing to happen to the sport in 20 years. Imo from what I've seen the only ones that could be up for debate are AI and T Mac. AI in his prime was the best player in the league, despite an ok team, a really poor work ethic and oh being barely 6 ft. If you transplant MJs mentality in AIs head he would have worked harder on the flaws in his game and would have been up for the GOAT debate. Better than MJ? I'm not sure, but he'd have some rings and some more MVPs to his name for sure. By the time MJ was 30 he was tearing up the Suns and winning his first three-peat. His insane work ethic allowed him to retire, play baseball for shits and giggles, come back and win a second three peat at 35 while still being the best player in the league. By the time AI was 30 he was playing in Denver and was already nearing the end of his career, and by 35 he was in Turkey nearing retirement. Imagine AI keeping up his 2001 form until at least 2007. Insane. T Mac was a taller bigger MJ with a 3 pointer. He lacked the discipline and the hustle in defense, and had he worked harder we would have seen less injuries and less flaws in his game. He could arguably do most things Mike did on offense, so he had the talent. He lacked that mentality and that makes him one of the biggest what ifs in the 2000s NBA. This said MJ didn't just have the mentality; he was a freak of nature with ginormous hands AND could jump 46 inches. He had feel for the ball and had a very delicate touch despite pizza pans for hands, and yet had the strength to run and dunk over bigger defenders. He was lethal from mid range and arguably could have been a decent 3 point shooter in todays more 3 oriented league. So to say AI and TMac may have been as talented, MAYBE. More talented, I don't think so.

I saw this the other day and I'm skeptical. Like I'm sure it yields results but when he said "how come we have all this technology and players are getting more injured" he honestly lost me. There's no correlation between bicep curls and your ACLs; you can lift dumbells all you want over your head but if you land awkwardly on your ankle you're fucked either way; you can add iron on iron but what happens if your achilles snaps? And the argument that he trained the best so he's gotta be right is really stupid. Jordan needed that muscle to deal with Detroit in 1991, not to handle injuries. From 1981 to 1990 MJ had virtually no weightlifting training and the only injury he had was a broken foot. He had no relevant muscle injuries and was the best player in the league for 5 years. Then he got big. So yeah some more muscle definitely do help but Grover is overselling it by a lot.

Premise being that big strong quads still don't save you from most knee injuries (they actually expose you more) he also talks negatively about cable training, which is what most leg training focuses around (leg press etc.). He specifically says that traditional weights ("lifting iron") are the solution, so I guess when it comes to the lower body he only means squats or deadlifts. And there are way better excercises than those to teach yourself how not to get injured (and they all involve medicine balls and rubber bands, the things he hated on throughout the whole video). My point is, like everything, you need a balance.

I agree with many saying that in hindsight it's really easy to pick MJ over Hakeem, I'd counter by saying that even in hindsight nothing assures you MJ flourishes on the Rockets. If I were a Houston fan, and had the chance to redo everything picking MJ with no certainty of winning anything, or keeping Hakeem and his two rings, I'd go the safe route. Maybe history repeats itself and MJ bags 6, maybe he only bags 3, maybe he does worse than Hakeem and doesn't win anything and gets traded amidst frustration within the organization. Hakeem got them two rings and is in the pantheon of GOAT centers. I'd say Houston fans are ok with that.

I'm just saying most Rockets fans wouldn't trade the two rings they got with Hakeem with the chance to win more rings but the risk of winning even less. We have the absolute certainty based off of the actual course of history that Hakeem was drafted first and won two rings. Can you say with the same objective certainty that Jordan on the Rockets wins more? Since nobody can reason off of "what if's" with absolute certainty, Rockets fans sit well with the idea of not drafting MJ in my opinion. Now Portland fans, that's a different story.
Of course, that's why I only mentioned the Rockets. The Portland dude who picked Sam Bowie over MJ is probably waking up screaming everyday lmao

I'm not making the assumption, I'm illustrating the number of possibilities out there. MJ could win more, less, the same, idk. Point is Rockets won two. Put it this way; you can either get 2 mil right now or flip a coin for a chance to win 6 mil or lose everything. What would you do?

His speed is insane for a basketball player, but on a soccer field he'd just be slightly faster than a normal CB or WB. Any other position requires a lot more technical ability and that increases the variables in this "what if" to an incalculable quantity.

No bro of course! It's hard to imagine a basketball player, a sport that requires a very particular, unique combination of physical traits, in another sporting context. I see Russ more as a fighter, as a boxer or mixed martial artist, because he's not too big and decently quick. However when it comes to soccer it's really hard to be as big as Russ is and still have a player like Robben's technical skills. CR7 is very unique in that sense, he's around 6'2, incredibly fast and incredibly technical. No player is that tall, fast and talented. Russ is 25 lbs heavier, around 7 cm taller, so even if he were as gifted technically he probably wouldn't be as agile and quick. Steve Nash on the other hand is the best example for a soccer player in the NBA. He was already playing when he was a kid and was pretty good at it, in a country where very few people play soccer. He's pretty tall too but much leaner than Russ, granting him more agility. He could have played as a CB or a decent midfielder if he had the right skills.

Were Olenna to be caught with the poison, she would foresake every Tyrell to ever live. The marriage would be off and half the family would be executed. In my opinion as readers we should avoid being anchored to cultural norms, western or westerosi. You can't deny there are characters that are very progressive, and others that are stubbornly conservative. When ethically or morally questioning fictional characters I tend to ask myself if that character found the right balance between naturally good and culturally appropriate. When I say naturally good I intend what scholars consider "natural law", intrinsic to human nature. Catelyn freeing Jaime, despite making emotionally sense, and despite being easy to empathize with, is overall the wrong choice, because it costs Robb the war. Robb marrying Jeyne is easily relateable, it's what any society without arranged marriages feels to be "normal", and yet it's a really bad decision, that also costs Robb the war. Ned killing a man for deserting is wrong through todays lens, and yet what else can he do? The wall is there for a reason, and needs to be manned for a reason. Cat is constantly questionable because when she does things the westerosi way, like her treatment of Jon, it's for nothing more than selfish reasons. And I'll grant that there are bastards with worse treatments, but there's also bastards with better treatments. And Ned treats Jon as a son in Cats eyes, and yet Ned is an honourable man, and Robb treats him like a brother, and he's her son. So why is she so hellbent on treating him this way? She is shown time and time again that another way is possible; yet she chooses to be stubborn and selfish. When she behaves like a mother would today, exchanging Jaime for Sansa and Arya, she still behaves stubbornly and selfishly. When Ned acts honourably, it is for the good of the realm; no good can come for him from pulling the rug on the parentage of the three incestuous spawn. And when he acts "dishonourably", lying to the whole kingdom about a certain bastard boy, this only attracts hate and resentment on his person, and yet he does it nonetheless, unselfishly.
