I don't know what line of work you're in and I think it's offensive to presume shit so, talking strictly for myself, I agree I'd rather live in the bubble right now but; 1. I'm used to my current living arrangements and this 9 to 5 routine inside the house; got used to it way before CoVid. Being locked down isn't that much different from my life before the pandemic. NBA players are used to taking jets anywhere if they feel like eating in a different city. My idea of a crazy night out is a restaurant 5 minutes away. I can't lecture them since we're clearly on different levels. 2. NBA players in the bubble are uber observed wherever they go, uber tested every 5 minutes, don't have much privacy outside of their rooms. They have coaching staff, journalists, facility staff and opponent staff always around them. 3. What is expected of me is run of the mill, standard work. I'm not really talking about "phoning it in" but what is expected of me is fairly ordinary. I don't have 50 cameras on me, millions of people expecting me to be better than someone else, who in turn is expected to beat me by millions of other people too. I have no one actively trying to stop me from being successful, I don't have that kind of stress. If I do my best, I succeed. If Chris Paul does his best it might not be enough, and it wasn't. So yeah, OF COURSE athletes sign up for that level of stress and are adequately compensated for it. But when you put them in ordinary conditions and still expect the extraordinary from them it might be stressful. I know it sounds stupid and immoral but when an athlete is "spoiled" it's normal for them to be somewhat demanding. It's no surprise every big star is complaining whereas it's only rookies or smaller names that are chill rn. 4. They have millions of people telling them they should appreciate what they have and that must be irritating too. I saw Javale's vlogs and their food is very meh, coming from me, a 23 y/o kid. What do you think an NBA player with private chefs and money to buy the best food will think? 5. I can switch off. I can stop working at 6, relax, focus on other stuff, not thinking about work. They have free time too, sure. Pool, spa, massages, etc. But is it really free time when you run into Russel Westbrook in the elevator knowing full well the outcome of your season depends on a game against him in 12 hours? Is it really off time? Is it relaxing? Or even running into your coach? Imagine relaxing in front of the TV and your boss barges into your house and sits down next to you. To an extent that's what it must feel like. 6. At the end of the day its better to stop judging them. Cause in their shoes I'd be the same. If I lived like Bron for a year I'd never want to go back. There's many more points that could be added. I don't want to sound patronizing but I feel like it's too easy to call them out for this stuff and its much harder to sit down, try to walk ten feet in their shoes and reflect on the lives of these athletes and what they go through, positives and negatives.

gt; Ok...thats your job. Context is that winning a championship is the pinnacle of a lifelong pursuit as an athlete. You are one of 60 players left that can impact that happening. This is the fucking moment that youve trained 100,000 hours minimum for. Every tool you need to be successful is at your disposal. Film rooms, gyms, whatever. Everything here only seems to put pressure on guys, not alleviate it. I might be wrong but I'd never want to have so many eyes on me.

gt;Aegon's first established law was the King's Peace, which forbid conflict in the realm without the leave of the #160;Iron Throne. Aegon treated the defeated lords with respect and allowed each region to retain its own laws and customs. The Targaryens in a way unified and brought peace. The different kingdoms before the conquest were separated and constantly at war. The Targaryen campaign was a unification of sorts. I know his name is Aegon the conqueror but at the end of the day those that surrendered kept lands, wealth, etc. All they lost was a title.

From what I read I wouldn't define as "terrible" what is run of the mill war. And not all kingdoms were annexed through war. The northerners didn't suffer anything terrible since Torrhen bent the knee asap. The Tullys didn't either. In general those that embraced the idea of one kingdom and not seven didn't lose anything, and actually gained peace. Only those that opposed the idea of unification lost lives and land.

Bend the knee and embrace peace or keep warring the neighboring kingdoms? I wouldn't neccesarily call it an unjust war. What Aegon did can be seen as noble if you squint your eyes hard enough. Those people lost their lives in the conquest because their rulers preferred to keep living in a state of constant conflict. This conquest was a war to end all wars, you might argue it was inevitable. Plus nobody had birthright to all of Westeros when Aegon pranced in. On the contrary Robert killed the rightful heir and had every possible heir killed as well. Going back to the main point, I'm not sure if it's accurate for Stannis to claim the throne when Dany is alive and strong. You'd need to study a lot of succession law in Westeros to understand it.

I don't get what's so big about the way they handled it. I'm from Italy and we were hit really hard by Covid, but when football (soccer) restarted there was no bubble. Players were justbreally careful with testing and masks and contact with other people and everyone was safe. Now the new season just began and unfortunately players laxed up on safety too much and new cases arose, but the summer period showed a bubble wasn't necessary to avoid new cases as long as everyone was careful. I'm not discrediting Silver, the bubble was a valorous, successful, and enormous effort, I'm just saying it might have been overkill and unnecessary.

I don't agree. Italy has now relaxed too much on safety measures, but when they restarted in June through August to end the past season no new cases arose. I think MJ doesn't get into this conversation because he can't physically beat Lebron right now; he can't jump back on the court and prove his dominance and I'm sure his competitive nature eats away at him. (From what I seem to understand of that man) he likes to prove he's better than you, and right now he can't so there's no point in talking about stuff that's hypythetical and that you can never really know.

*1. A total loser without Pippen* I could argue Mikes numbers from 1984 to 1990 were still astonishing; numbers which, despite losing, still show just how dominant he was, but that would be useless. It's true, Mike never did win much with a shitty team of unprofessional cocaine snorting assholes. What I'll argue is that when Pip was the leader in 1994, with a great team, and the best coach ever, he showed what he was made of. Not only weren't his skills enough, he disappointed the team from a leadership standpoint. Compare that to LeBron who could count on D-Wade and AD on 3 of his 4 rings. Worth to note that MJ and Pip were the only two players on both three-peats. People love to say how Mikes teams got good only when Pip developed and yet never mention how important Mike was in his development. And anyway, you could argue the real gamechanger was Phil and the triangle, cause Pip and MJ + Doug Collins failed miserably. Also, LeBron is also a total loser without good teammates. He needed Bosh and Wade to win his first ring. He needed AD to win his 4th. And even without Kyrie his third is improbable. *2. Never once beat Larry Bird* April 20, 1986. Larry Bird on record saying "that was just God disguised as Michael Jordan" and "that's the greatest player ever". MJ didn't win that game but the person used in this example invalidates this second point. If Larry Bird is a benchmark for greatness, Larry Bird saying you're God at 23 must mean something. And I remind you, it's of a SOPHOMORE Michael Jordan. Imagine Luka Doncic playing so well Lebron is forced to say that this is the best player ever, adding it's God disguised as Luka. That was GOAT level shit from Mike considering he just got better since 1986. *3. Could never beat a Super Team* That is complete BS. Firstly because back then there were no such things as superteams, secondly because the closest thing to a superteam was the Jazz with two HOFers / Dream Team players and he handed their ass to them in 6. Twice. Back to back. *4. The East was terrible* Firstly, that's bullshit. MJ beat 5 different West teams in the finals, showing even if the East were to be easier, he still was better than the best the West had to offer. The thing about more than 1 Hall of Famer was really dumb. The 1991 Lakers and the 97-98 Jazz had 2 HOFers (but Mike still beat them), but the Blazers, the Suns and the Sonics all had 1 HOFer. The 94 Rockets had only Hakeem before adding Clyde the year later. Point is, even teams in the West didn't usually have more than 1 HOFer. And besides that, winning contributes to your HOF status. So of course if Penny had won he might be a HOFer right now, same goes for Horace Grant. Unfortunately, they were stopped in 96 by a man called Michael Jordan. *5. Everyone won rings on his watch* It's easy when you take his Wizards stint, but we all know those seasons have an asterisk when considering Jordans career. His rookie years are dumb too, considering how bad his team was. And Hakeem and Drexler are also dumb considering he played half a season after coming back from baseball. You can maybe hold the 87/88 Lakers and the 89-90 Pistons over his head. If you reason like he did everyone won rings on LeBrons watch; Duncan, Ginobili, Parker, Kawhi, Kobe, Gasol, Pierce, Rondo, Garnett, Nowitzki, Jason Kidd, D Wade, Shaq, Curry, Klay, Durant, Draymond, even the fucking Big Ben-Chauncey Billups Detroit Pistons. What a random fact to state to support LeBrons cause. Stephen A Smith said a smart thing yesterday: if I'm a hater for saying LeBron is number 2 keep calling me a hater, but I think you have your priorities wrong son. Edits: some formatting and grammar

Are you saying Magic is overrated? Cause honestly you'd lose me right there. Magic is the consensus best PG all time, even though he might be surpassed by Steph one day. The thing about the evolution of the league, of course the game has evolved. That's obvious! Players are getting bigger, faster, stronger, the game is less sectorialized (big men shoot 3s, little men drive and dunk). Injuries are treated better. I love Letitia Wright as a sidekick, but I think she lacks the acting experience and in general the persona to carry the franchise on her back. I'm not against the idea of having a female BP but I think the right choice is Lupita Nyongo, since it makes sense not just from a business standpoint but from a narrative standpoint too. I loved the serious Tchalla-joking Shuri dynamic, and that would still work with Nakia as a protagonist. She has the field experience to be BP and she would actually be queen if she married Tchalla in this off time (could be retconned I guess). That being said, when an actor dies in a big franchise it's really hard to work around it; in the Fast franchise they did a great job when Paul Walker died, but being mid-production it was also easier. To explain T'challas disappearance they'd need to either kill him offscreen, which is a huge copout and is completely unsatisfying, or justify his departure offscreen, which would be unrealistic considering he just became king and barely had any adventures. That's why I'm not against the unfortunate idea of recasting him, keeping the franchise with T'challa. T'challa as a character is too important to Marvel to be eliminated so soon. Having appeared in just 4 movies, with two of them having barely any screen time and lines, and just one as a protagonist, I don't feel like it's too late.

MJ is 6-0 with 6 fMVP, those six coming in two three peats and in theory are 6 in a row if you only count his full seasons. This isn't to discredit what a fucking baller Tim was but it's easy to forget just how out of this world MJ was.

I don't agree, not all families are built the same. This opinion is anything but unpopular, but I still don't fully agree with it. I'm 23 and handle all of that shit myself indipendently, but it's only because I grew up in a family where I had to do that in order to survive. I don't think good parenting necessarily teaching you how to do that stuff; rather it's transmitting a sense of responsability that brings you to a place one day where you're able, willing, and happy to learn how to do all of this stuff. You're first day living on your own your bed will be a mess, the pasta you cooked is gonna taste like shit and your dishes won't be squeaky clean, but as long as your parents inspired the right attitude you'll slowly learn.
